comments.commentBody: I think men should work since women gestate, give birth, breast feed and do the majority of house hold work and child raising. asking women to work too is inequitable and unfair to women. Men need to start contributing to families, society and the human race.
13 years one job and 12 the next, I had no idea I was not the norm....

My wife never worked outside the home. This worked well until the 1973 oil embargo and the ensuing inflation. I knew that to enable my wife to be at home when our children returned from school each day, I had to increase my income above average salary increases, so I started a business. That took care of inflation because I could raise prices to compensate for it. I left my corporate job so that my wife did not have to work.

Wars in the Middle East resulting in the increasing price of energy have been the primary source of inflation. I believe it was the increased cost of oil and its impact on the entire economy that led women to finding it necessary to take a job outside the home.

The attached link shows the participation rate for male and females from 1948 through 2002. The Bureau of Labor Statistics discontinued the report in 2002 and went to an overall participation rate.

Relevant factors that may have affected the participation rate for women from the late 40's through the early 70's were the Baby Boom, the Korean War, and the Vietnam War.

The addition of women to the workforce may have had some affect on the wages that men earned but I believe the diminished power of the Unions and outsourcing is more responsible for the decrease in male earnings than the addition of women to the workforce.
This is just a guess, but if women entering the workforce had a negative affect on wages it is more likely to be in the professional classes such as lawyers and accountants.

http://data.bls.gov...

Really, the issue is why are there two separate and very unequal insurance systems in this country? One for large employers, Federal and state employees, Medicare recipients, Veterans, and the other for small businesses and individuals.
Why is this second-rate market for individuals, the self-employed and small employers even allowed to legally exist? Medical underwriting should just be abolished, period. Health care is essential, it is not like airline seating. People should not be forced to pay three times what their neighbor pays for the exact same insurance coverage, just because they don't work for a Fortune 500 company.

Yes, the unions are quite capable of renewing the carve-out. If they got it the first time, no reason why they couldn't get it a second time.

Yes, this is a great issue for Republicans because it is so blatantly unfair.
Lots of low income workers have jobs that are physically demanding but often leave them too worn out to spend time doing actual exercise.

China has experienced tremendous economic growth without a democracy. I agree with you that economic growth doesn't always mean shared benefits (a rising tide doesn't lift all boats) but in China, it's not because of too many gov't programs. There is bad gov't and good gov't.

In China, the gov't has chosen not to invest it's new wealth in the people as much as it might. It builds roads and bridges, but not earthquake proof schools. The Chinese gov't has been very effective at facilitating Chinas ecomonic growth. It has not "gotten in the way".

Given that the top 10% of American earn as much (or represent the wealth of) the bottom 90 percent, the only way a significant number of Americans can afford healthcare is to have it subsidized by the people with more money. It's not about people on high telling you what to do. It's about the well off sharing responsibility for the less well off.

My problem with the current plan is that, based on what is now known, we are not asking the wealthiest to shoulder more of the costs. We are the wealthiest country in the world, but the wealth is concentrated at the top and for some unfathomable reason, we seem unwilling to ask them to contribute a little extra from that wealth for the benefit of their fellow citizens.

Unregulated capitalism concentrates money and power at the top. That is why we needed trust busting laws, and that is why we need income taxes. A rising tide does not lift all boats. What good is democracy if your vote is for a gov't that doesn't have money to do anything?

We no longer live in a country where land giveaways by the gov't are the means of providing opportunities of upwards mobility. In fact, the last land giveaway resulted in the catastrophe of the Dustbowl.

In our metro area the landscape is littered with new strip malls, storefronts and buildings which have been eerily empty for the last 2 yrs.I wonder how long the paper can be held on these buildings. This coupled with dramatic changes in consumer spending and business cutting back on the amount and quality of office space looks foreboding. Add to this the large retailers and box stores which cluttered the metro areas with more stores to get the consumer dollar and you have another iron in the fire.In the Portland/Vancouver metro area we have thousands of new condos,high rise apartments and lofts that are not being sold. It is not unusual to see a multistory buildings with only a handful of residents.Short of a miraculous economic recovery these buildings will remain under occupied. I have several friends involved in the commercial real estate market in various capacities and not a single one has any optimism. They are all waiting for the shoe to drop.

Constantly worrying about losing your job may be worse for your health than actually getting laid off or being unemployed, according to a study published in the September issue of the journal Social Science and Medicine. By analyzing two large, long-term data sets for some 1,700 U.S. workers, sociologists from the University of Michigan and the University of California at Los Angeles found that the persistent stress of not knowing whether you'll be employed the next year was strongly correlated with people reporting both poorer health, and higher incidence of depressive symptoms.

Welcome to the miracle of Free Market Conservative Republican Neoliberal Economics.

Who needs you to work for them? We just outsource your job.

Why do you think everywhere is cutting public education? Why should we waste the money on training and educating all of you unemployed people and your children when we are just going to outsource your job anyway?

And if we can't outsource it we will give it to legal and illegal immigrants.

We need a large pool of unemployed to keep wages down and eliminate the middle-class.

Welcome the the conservative nirvana of the Free Market.
You should re-title this as "A Modest Proposal" and submit it as an op ed piece.

These two paragraphs are at the end of the BLS news release on the topic.

http://stats.bls.gov...

Interpreting Tenure Data

Data on tenure have been used as a gauge of employment security, with some
observers regarding increases in tenure as a sign of improving security and
decreasing tenure as a sign of deteriorating security. However, there are
limitations to using the data in this way. For example, during recessions
or other periods of declining job security, median tenure and the proportion
of workers with long tenure could rise because less-senior workers are more
likely to lose their jobs than are workers with longer tenure. During periods
of economic growth, median tenure and the proportion of workers with long
tenure could fall because more job opportunities are available for new en-
trants to the workforce and experienced workers have more opportunities to
change employers and take better jobs. Tenure also could rise under im-
proving economic conditions, however, as fewer layoffs occur and good job
matches develop between workers and employers.

A changing age distribution among workers would also affect median tenure.
Since older workers are more likely to have long tenure with their current
employer than younger workers, aging baby boomers in the workforce would
provide upward pressure on overall median tenure.

While I don't like just unions being exempted from the tax for an additional 5 years, I do applaud the fact that they negotiated to have the thresholds adjusted by a firm's average age, gender composition and industry group. These are things that should have been done in the first place.

A recent Health Affairs article argued that only about 6% of the variation in premiums is explained by actuarial value (i.e. how rich the benefits are), with the above 3 factors accounting for a lot. I suspect a lot of the variation is due to how efficient a plan is at keeping its members healthy and containing costs. The excise tax will now target inefficient plans a bit better - in the previous form it was a blunt instrument, although I would still have supported it.

According to this index, Bulgaria is the least miserable country surveyed (so says the WSJ, I haven't seen the whole report). With a dimwit prime minister who used to be in Secret Service and greedy incompetent politicians, any aid given to one of the EU's poorest member gets pocketed before it can do any good. Regular people can hardly afford to pay their bills and support their families. The elderly are getting by on laughable monthly pensions.

If there is one thing that's true about Bulgaria, it's that everyone always complains and no one is ever happy. The least miserable country on the list though--that Bulgaria simply ain't.

A few notes/thoughts:
- Tenure is even shorter for people in advertising, marketing and generally those companies that "value" turnover.
- Our economy is not set up for this. Employer-based healthcare is an accident of WWII. Benefits are dropping, tenure is dropping, 401ks are dropping.
- Interesting on the public sector. Basically they don't get paid bad then get a good pension and healthcare for life. I don't know how cities and states will afford this, but it is easier for politicians to give in rather than take a strike.
- Our laws favor the larger companies. Such things as working at their pleasure with their ability to be rid of you for basically anything - performance, fall off in business, age, outsourceing, etc. is going to cause a sincere rethinking of the whole work scene by the people caught in it. No matter what BS they say, you are, as a worker, a replaceable cog in the machine. HR finds ways to say this all nicer, but they are duped instruments that carry out the policies. HUMAN Resources - HA.
- We live in a world where about 1.6 billion Indians and Chinese will work for a dollar a day or less - if I hear another politician talk about free trade, I'll scream.

That's my opinion and I'm sticking to it.

Calling people who earn 90k "rich" is stretching things a bit. As does the definition of "exercise" as an arbitrary minimum of 30 minutes a day. And like other commenters, I think people exaggerate the amount of exercise they do in such a poll - perhaps "rich" people more than poor, due to concern with self-image and status.

When all is said and done the only person who counts is the one in the mirror, though: you can try and lie to yourself, but it doesn't work long. Even someone who's destitute can walk for 20 minutes a day or do a short bodyweight workout. And many may, but Gallup won't count that as exercise.

Michael
http://taoofbachelorhood.com

Rich people do not have more free time. There's a huge correlation between hours worked and income. (No one claims that income differences stem simply from work hours. The more you earn per hour worked, the more tempting it is to work more hours and pocket the money.)

Anyone who doubts this assertion can check out dozens of studies that confirm this. Here's an analysis of some of those studies that The Times printed in 2008: http://www.nytimes.com...

A much fuller account can be found in the write-up of this meta-analysis, which is sadly in pdf format: http://www.bos.frb.org...

But my main concern isn't the relationship between income and leisure. There's a more important point here.

Blogs are a great place for people to express their opinions and to present factual data that the blogger missed, forgot or omitted. But there's no excuse in a moderated blog hosted by the world's most prestigious paper for false assertions of fact.

Two comment writers have made simple assertions that are demonstrably false -- and wildly false at that. Indeed, the negative correlation between income and leisure is well enough known that I'd bet Catherine Rampell would have spotted the error immediately.

That may be too much to ask for someone who moderates comments on many blogs rather than specializing in economics, but errors still have to be caught if these blogs are to be a place where readers get information rather than misinformation.

Instead of rejecting erroneous comments outright, I think the paper should publish them, along with a polite response indicated that while X may be conventional wisdom, it is false. (If research hasn't been conclusive then that should be mentioned.)

The "white collar keyboarding cubicle rats" as AnnS puts its, are already hard hit by outsourcing and will continue to be. We are not nearly at the end of the drain of information-based occupations that are being sent overseas. Any job done sitting in front of a keyboard and monitor will eventually wind up in India, where wages are 20-30% of the wages here.

When I look at the classifieds in the paper, I am struck by how many of the employment ads are in health care, gov't and education, and the non-profit sector. There don't seem to be any jobs in the private sector anymore. This is the result of 15+ years of free trade where the trading partners get to play by entirely different rules, low wages, no worker protections, no environmental laws. I am not a protectionist, but how could anyone not see that this would be an end result? Time to reverse course and craft a FAIR trade policy, not just a free one, that will benefit everyone, not just those at the top.

And don't give me the canard about how we all benefit from the cheap imports, what I might save in a year of shopping at Wal-Mart wouldn't cover my health insurance premium for even a month.
Congrats! Those were some great games.

Nice gesture. But John Calipari you have to be careful. He's the kind of fellow who could rob your mother at gun point -- in front of you -- and leave you believing he had done her a good favor.

Bottom line: Watch John Calipari closely and keep your distance. It's not you or Haiti he seeks to serve; it's himself.

My wife went along with her newly wed friends in their honeymoon. They stay in four seasons hotel and did not go anywhere outside the hotel resort. The last night, they decided to go to eat at Mozaic, Bali because it is quite famous there. She put on her skirt the first time there thinking it will be safe and properly dressed for Mozaic. After they dined at their outdoor patio, they found themselves had at least 10 mosquito/insect bites "on each leg" and the bites are so allergic, painful and itchy that they had to see doctors after they got back to their country.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/46060105@N05/
(The pattern of these bites are proves that she was biten when she is still and wearing a skirt)

They contacted the general manager and the chef owner, and all they did were saying sorry and they said the insect bites is not due to any fault of Mozaic. We asked for at least the refund of her dinner expense but they only only offer a complimentary glass of champagne next she is there. The former general manager there even suggested that she should uses a strong insect repellent when she visit South East Asia. My wife and I went to Bangkok, Tailand for 4 days, walking at day and night on the street in Bangkok and a remote city visiting a monk, and nothing happened. How can they do not offer any hospitality and accept the insect problem at their patio dinning area is their responsiblity if they offer guest to dine there?
He does very well in the film along with everyone else including Mr. Hollwyood Musical, Zac Efron who iis really a fine actor. It is a pity that so few people have gone to see this excellent movie.

It is a pity that great films don't get any attention unless its stars, producers, directors, etc go out and dance on the sidewalk so somebody will throw some acclaim their way. The entire award season is a sordid, contrived dog wedding.
